title: Infering interaction from (non-)significance
text:
In a clinical trial, a group of 30 patients is assigned drug A, and another group of 30 patients drug B. Those who take drug A show a significant improvement in symptoms, \(M_D = 0.23\), 95% CI \([0.06, 0.40]\), \(t(29) = 2.78\), \(p = .009\). Those who take drug B show no significant change in symptoms, \(M_D = 0.04\), 95% CI \([-0.12, 0.20]\), \(t(29) = 0.50\), \(p = .618\). It is concluded that drug A is more effective than drug B.
The conclusion above, that the effect of drug A is different to the effect of drug B, may seem persuasive. But it is wrong. The claim that an effect differs between two groups refers to an interaction, and evidence for that claim should be based on a direct test of that interaction (Gelman and Stern 2006). A direct test of the interaction provides no evidence of a difference in effect, \(F(1, 58) = 2.72\), \(p = .105\), \(\hat{\eta}^2_G = .002\), 90% CI \([.000, .053]\).
If you look at the data in the figure below, it is reasonably clear that the improvement from pretest to postest is not so different between the drugs, and hence why there is no evidence for an interaction between time and drug. The average difference between the posttest and pretest is small for both drugs, but just large enough to be significant for drug A. For drug B, there is also an improvement on average, but this is not strong enough to be significant. But that the difference is significant in one group, and not the other, is itself no evidence that the difference differs between groups.





Plot of (simulated) scores by time and drug.




In 2011, Nieuwenhuis, Forstmann, and Wagenmakers (2011) found the error to be very pervasive in neuroscience. Out of 513 articles in top journals, 79 made the error, compared to 78 using the correct direct test of the interaction. More recently,
Garcia-Sifuentes and Maney (2021) show that out of 83 articles claiming evidence for sex differences, only 32 (39%) used the correct procedure of testing an interaction directly.
So, beware of claims made from patterns of significance over multiple tests. They could be correct, but there is no way to tell. A claim of an interaction should be supported by a direct test of that interaction effect.




References

Garcia-Sifuentes, Yesenia, and Donna L Maney. 2021. “Reporting and Misreporting of Sex Differences in the Biological Sciences.” Elife 10: e70817.


Gelman, Andrew, and Hal Stern. 2006. “The Difference Between ‘Significant’ and ‘Not Significant’ Is Not Itself Statistically Significant.” The American Statistician 60 (4): 328–31.


Nieuwenhuis, Sander, Birte U Forstmann, and Eric-Jan Wagenmakers. 2011. “Erroneous Analyses of Interactions in Neuroscience: A Problem of Significance.” Nature Neuroscience 14 (9): 1105–7.

title: About
text: The UCL Centre for Behavioural Data Science promotes the effective and responsible use of data science to better understand and predict human behaviour across a wide variety of contexts. This blog is part of that aim.
